TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The important point to realise is that the average enrolment per division in 1949 was 39,948. In March 1983, it was just under 75,000, an increase of 87.7 per cent. If the Representation Bill is passed and the increase in the number of members in the House of Representatives is granted, there will still be as of March 1983 about 63,000 enrolments in each electoral division. That represents an increase of some 58.5 per cent on the 1949 figures. It is important to realise that these enrolments are growing at a terrific pace. Take the average enrolment figures per electorate for New South Wales. I have not done the figures for the other States. In March 1983, when we prepared the report, it was 63,687; it is now 65,000. The figure has already increased by nearly 1,500 in just six months or so. In addition to that, one of the recommendations which everybody has accepted and which is now in the Bill is the compulsory enrolment of Aborigines. From now on it will be compulsory for Aboriginal people to enrol. I cannot recall the figures of the extra numbers involved but obviously in many electorates there will be a significant number. That factor in itself will again increase the average enrolment in each electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: In the couple of minutes that I have left before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I will quickly refer to some of the arguments which have been made by other honourable members before I get on to my main argument in favour of increasing the number of members in the House of Representatives. Among the arguments for such an increase in the number of enrolments, is the claim that a larger parliament would strengthen the operation of the parliamentary system, a great number of extra responsibilities have been put on parliamentarians and on Parliament itself, access of electors to political representatives is demanded more now than it has been in the past and, most importantly, the growing involvement by the Federal Parliament in additional issues since 1949. I think everybody would agree that the list is impressive. The list includes: Aboriginal affairs, more extensive social welfare and health policies, uniform legislation such as company law, education, environment and conservation, family law, status of women, law reform and legal aid, ethnic affairs, consumer affairs, child care , minerals and energy policy, tourism and small business, sport and recreation, cultural affairs and the national heritage, federal affairs and local government , science and technology, electronic communications such as television and satellites, an expanded industrial relations role for the Federal Parliament, more complex economic issues and greater involvement in overseas aid. I think that anybody who reflects on these extra responsibilities which have been added to the responsibilities of the Federal Parliament and of Federal parliamentarians since 1949, in addition to the, I think, 87 per cent increase in the number of electors we each represent, must surely see that either the people who were in Parliament in 1949 were tremendously under-employed or obviously more members are now needed. Before we break for dinner, I will deal with one extra point which the honourable member for Boothby made. It was about the extra bureaucracy and the extra cost involved in having an additional 23 members and 12 senators. The honourable member suggested an extra staff member for each member of Parliament. That would give us an extra 189 staff members; at present there are 189 parliamentarians.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting, honourable members will recall , I pointed out that this was a real consensus piece of legislation dealing with the increase in the size of Parliament. I pointed out that when the Committee was set up the honourable member for Boothby, who led for the Liberal Party of Australia, moved a motion to increase the number of members in Parliament. The National Party of Australia made the recommendation for the increase and presented the arguments. For practical purposes, members on the Committee adopted the recommendation from the National Party for very good reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: I pointed out that the Federal Parliament-quite apart from the fact that the last increase in the number of members was in 1949-has now got a very large number of additional issues which the people in 1948-49 never thought about as being Federal issues. Two members of the Committee dissented. As I pointed out earlier, the honourable member for Boothby dissented-to some extent it contradicts his present position-on the basis that it would be better to give an extra staff member to every one of the 189 parliamentarians at present. He considered that the extra staff member would be better than adding the extra parliamentarian. Senator Sir John Carrick, who was the other Liberal Party member on the Committee, reacted with the usual sort of argument used in the United States when somebody is asked whether a particular person claims to be a progressive republican. He is then asked the difference between a progressive republican and a conservative republican and says that a conservative republican is against change whilst a progressive republican is in favour of change but not now. That was exactly the attitude taken by Senator Sir John Carrick on this issue. He supported the increase but he felt that this was not an opportune time to go ahead with the increase and stated his reasons, which are basically economic, and contradicted his colleague who is leading for the Liberal Party in this House.

One of the arguments presented by the honourable member for Boothby-I think it is an argument that is accepted by others-is that the increase would interfere with the running of Parliament because six people will be elected from each State for the Senate at each Senate election and, therefore, the Senate will be deadlocked all the time. I have some difficulty in accepting that proposition because in fact it is likely that either the Australian Democrats or some other minority party will win the sixth seat in most cases and the remaining five seats in each state will be divided on the basis of which major party, in effect , wins the election in that particular State. But even if the proposition were true that the Senate were divided or that the Government will always have to depend on minority parties, I am not completely convinced that that is a bad thing. I know that it is, to some extent, going against the sorts of propositions we usually have to put in this House. My own view-I have expressed it before-is reflected in one of the editorials of the Sydney Morning Herald. The article states:
. . . the committee's arguments in favour of its recommendation are plausible and deserve more than the simplistic response that Australia already has too many politicians.
There are two main arguments in favour of expanding the size of the House of Representatives.

The article pointed out that the expansion of the Senate is as a result of the nexus provision in the Constitution. It stated that one argument is because of the growth in population, et cetera. I have dealt with that matter. The article continued:
The second argument is one for more legislators-
the word 'legislators' is reflected in dark black-

to increase the effectiveness of the Parliament as a countervailing force to the executive government, which has grown substantially since 1949. This is a worthy objective but there is nothing to suggest that this would necessarily follow from a larger House of Representatives. The failure of the House, unlike the Senate, to develop an effective Committee system, or similar procedures to more effectively scrutinise legislation, has been one of its own making.

To some extent that is true. I think it is changing. We have accepted the proposition that it would be a good idea to have more committees, either joint committees between the two Houses or committees of this House, dealing with issues rather than leaving it to the Senate committees. I certainly hope that the House will continue to insist on that proposition. I previously stated my own views that I do not think that the main aim of parliamentarians should be to be legislators. My own view would be that the increase in the number of parliamentarians would in fact reduce the proportion of the Executive or the so- called legislators in the party room. This would force the Executive to persuade a larger number of potential critics and maybe sometimes fail to do so. We have a situation at present where a large proportion of the Government party meetings are in fact members of the Ministry and those who have some other position which , in some way, ties them to a large extent to the Executive position in the broadest sense.

In the administration of the Fraser Government it is true to say that once matters came to the party room it was extremely difficult to raise issues to change a government decision. I have never been particularly impressed by claims of consecutive governments of varying political complexion that the number of laws passed is in any way related to the ultimate benefit for the Australian population. The Whitlam Government was terribly keen and proud to say that it passed more laws than any previous Government in its first 12 months or so. The Fraser Government was elected on the basis that it would reduce the amount of legislation. At the end of the first year of its term in office the then Prime Minister Fraser was terribly proud that he had passed more pieces of legislation in the first 12 months than Whitlam had in his first 12 months.

The relationship between benefits to the Australian population and the number of pieces of legislation passed is not proportionate. I would in fact argue that it is often in inverse proportion. In any case we need a significant number of members who are prepared to spend their time looking at proposed legislation and exposing it to more effective criticism both in parliamentary and party committees and in the party room and, in cases where it is appropriate, to changing the legislation and influencing their parties to change the legislation before it is introduced into Parliament. Simplistic parliamentarians are beloved of the media. Others are aware that 'solutions' often lead to more 'problems'. If a politician says that he is not 100 per cent sure and it is unlikely that any decision is a black and white decision but usually they are different shades of grey, the media criticises him. Often the net result is that-with all due respect to the people involved-the people who become leaders have at least to pretend to be rather simplistic and rather simple minded and to be prepared to claim they know the solutions to all the problems. My own view is that there are no solutions to many of the problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANTHONY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that my contribution to this debate tonight will be objective, rational, unemotional and certainly without any party political bias. I believe that it is proper and necessary for there to be some modest increase in the size of the Parliament for the proper working of our parliamentary system. Any suggestion that the National Party of Australia supports this move for a party political advantage should be rejected. If I felt that the Australian Labor Party, or any party for that matter, were to get a political advantage out of increasing the size of the Senate and the House of Representatives I for one certainly would not support the move. The only advantage that I can see is that on average electorates will be made slightly smaller than they are now and that gigantic electorates will be made marginally smaller. To that extent my Party will get an advantage. The National Party does not hold all the gigantic electorates; they are shared by all political parties in this Parliament. That is the only party political advantage that one can claim about my support for the increase in the size of Parliament. I hope that during this debate I can demonstrate my sincerity for stating that the Party believes that it is necessary to make this proposed increase.

SPEECH.PARA: Seventeen years ago in 1966, all the major parties agreed that there was a need to increase the size of the House of Representatives. The only exception was the Australian Democratic Labor Party which, of course, did not have representation in the House of Representatives, only in the Senate. In this House there was a bipartisan approach. The Liberal Party, the Australian Country Party, as it was at the time, and the Labor Party all agreed that there was a need to increase the size of Parliament. At that time there had not been any increase in the past 17 years. The size of electorates had increased rapidly. We had the post-war immigration program and the rapid increase in the population. Everybody could see a need for an increase in size. That was in 1966. In 1983 we can demonstrate that case more clearly and strongly.

I happened to be the Minister for the Interior at the time. It was my job then to organise a referendum to try to break the nexus between the Senate and the House of Representatives. Under the Constitution the House of Representatives can be only twice the size of the Senate; so we cannot increase the size of this chamber unless we also increase the size of the Senate. In 1966 we felt that the only increase in the Senate could be from 10 to 14 senators for each State, but of course that would have meant 24 more senators and 48 more members of the House of Representatives, an increase of 72. That was unacceptable and nobody subscribed to that point of view. By breaking the nexus we would have been able to leave the Senate at the same size, 10 from each State, and increase the size of the House of Representatives to a figure which would be determined on the basis of the number of people in each electorate.

The reason we decided the numbers had to be increased from 10 to 14 was that if we had a half Senate election we would have needed an odd number, so that whoever won the majority of votes at the time of the Senate and House of Representatives election would command the majority of Senate positions and therefore have a better chance of controlling both the House of Representatives and the Senate. If we increased the numbers only from 10 to 12 it would have meant that six senators from each State must stand for re-election. Therefore the likelihood of a deadlock, with the Labor Party winning three seats and the non-Labor parties winning three seats, was very likely. That idea was rejected; so we tried to break the nexus.

We had the referendum. In fact, four questions were put, but only one dealt with the nexus. Three questions were passed, but the question relating to breaking the nexus was rejected in a way that no other referendum question in this country has been rejected. The vote was 3.4 million against and 2.3 million for. The only State which carried the question was New South Wales. The catchcry , led by the Democratic Labor Party and by Senator Reg Wright and Senator Ian Wood from Queensland in the end-they did not start off with the catchcry-was that there were too many politicians, and that the proposed increase was costly. Of course, as we all know, in Australian folklore politicians become--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fair game.

—Fair game for anybody. They are lampooned, belted and bashed. The electorate got its message through about how much it loved politicians. That did not stop one from believing in what was right and proper. Certainly, I believed it was right and proper. My own electorate of Richmond was the only rural electorate in Australia to carry an affirmative vote, because I went out and tried to explain. I believed that it was necessary for the proper workings of this Parliament that there be some increase. It did not work that way. Those people who now say that we ought to have another go at breaking the nexus, whilst I would be quite prepared to accept the challenge, should realise that it is a waste of time. I think the same emotional reaction would occur again and we would lose. We would be in the same position we are in at the moment; we will either never increase the size of this House of Parliament or we must accept that we have to increase the size of both the Senate and the House of Representatives at the one time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform was set up by this Parliament in the May session to look into the electoral system. It is probably one of the most comprehensive reviews that have ever been carried out. When the Government announced the terms of reference I suggested in this House that included in the terms of reference ought to be the matter of the number of members of Parliament . I felt that that was probably one of the most important matters the Committee could look at. The Government was reluctant to include that matter in the Committee's terms of reference. I believed that it was appropriate because we had tried several years earlier, 16 years earlier, to get an increase. Therefore , with the population and electorates having increased and with the work of members of parliament having increased dramatically, surely that was the time to look at the matter. It was also appropriate because we were to have a redistribution. The imbalance in the size of the electorates was obvious and there had to be a general redistribution throughout Australia. It seemed appropriate that unless we considered the matter then maybe two or three terms of Parliament would go by before we considered it again when the next redistribution came up. It seems appropriate that as we are to move into the new Parliament House in 1988 now is the time to consider any increase in the number of members of Parliament.

The Government set up its joint review Committee and called for submissions by all interested parties. The National Party, through its State organisations, prepared detailed submissions, covering the whole gamut of the terms of reference, which were presented to that Committee for consideration. We included in the New South Wales submission reasons why the Parliament ought to be increased. They were put forward for serious consideration and the Committee, after looking at the question closely, and with the support of the National Party representative on the Committee, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt ), recommended in favour. The two Liberal Party representatives, Senator Sir John Carrick and the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), have put in minority reports rejecting the increase. But both Senator Sir John Carrick and the honourable member for Boothby acknowledged that there would be a need at some point to increase the size of Parliament. I quote from the minority report of Senator Sir John Carrick:

In my view, while the logic of a larger parliament is strong, the overriding restraints of the current economic period must prevail. I therefore believe that the question should be deferred and its various aspects (including the nexus) put under further study.

It we accepted that, we would not be looking at the matter for probably another ten years. But there is an acknowledgement of an argument in favour of an increase. I do not believe that in the argument one should rely heavily on the question of economic circumstances. Who knows what the economic circumstances will be in just two years from now? This increase will most likely not apply until two to three years from now. The honourable member for Boothby in his minority report also recognised these factors. He said:
The public would rightly be offended if the size of the Federal Parliament was increased at a time when many businesses were reducing the number of their employees because of the recession.
He went on:
My view does not hold that there should never be an increase. Population growth will make this desirable probably at the end of the century.

So the correct time to increase the numbers becomes a matter of argument or debate. I believe that the correct time is now. It is 34 years since there has been an increase, and that is a very substantial argument. But the question now is whether we should increase to twelve, the number of senators representing a State. I said before that there was a reluctance to increase the number to twelve because it would cause a 3-3 split in a State. But increasing the number to twelve will not necessarily mean that the Government of the day will or will not get control of the Senate. I must admit that it will probably make it a little harder for the Government, but since I came to this Parliament in 1958 there have been 11 elections and the Government of the day has had control of the Senate in only four of those elections-those of 1958, 1975, 1977 and 1980. In 1980 the then Government had control of the Senate for only a short period until the period of the retiring senators expired and the new senators came in, so it lost control of the Senate in 1981.

The fact of the matter is that most times these days the Government has a minority in the Senate or there is a hung Senate. With the advent, firstly, of the Democratic Labor Party and, today, the Australian Democrats and the Independents it seems that in some States at least one of those elected to the Senate will be an Australian Democrat or an Independent. The split between the two major parties, the parties contesting government, will be between five senators. The winner of the day will get three senators and the other party will get two. but if the argument is that somehow or other an increase will distort the pattern-I have heard the argument that the Australian Labor Party is likely to benefit because of the block vote in the Senate and it is always likely to get three of the six seats more quickly than anybody else-the statistics I have had worked out by the Parliamentary Library do not show this to be conclusive. We can see that the pattern varies from State to State and from election to election and it is very hard for any political party to get up to the magic figure of 42.84 per cent, which a party requires for the election of three senators in one State. I have the figures for the elections of 1977-I did not include those for 1975 because I feel they were distorted-1980 and 1983 and I would like to have those incorporated in Hansard. I have also had the Parliamentary Library do a calculation on the outcome of the three elections based on having six senators or 12 senators just to show that there is not a substantial variation in the overall percentage figures at any time. I seek leave to have the tables incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Party supports the proposal for a modest increase in the number of senators. We believe this proposal recognises the reality of the work of Parliament today. We believe an increase in the size of Parliament is warranted and that now is the right time to take action to bring about that increase. The fact that this proposal is not popular in the community does not mean that it is wrong. Many of the things that parliaments and governments do are unpopular, but that does not mean that they are wrong. If we believe something is right we have a duty to support it and do it. The National Party believes that it is in the national interest, that it is for the better working of our democracy that this Parliament be increased. To suggest that there is not to be any increase is unreal and to suggest that there will not be an increase in the foreseeable future is ridiculous and indefensible. The need exists and I hope nobody will put any other interpretation on the National Party's support for this decision. Some people might want to make mischief out of the fact that the ALP has reacted favourably to our suggestion, saying that we are voting with it or that it is voting with us. We believe that it is the correct measure, popular or not.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spent a large part of my time in this place working to implement things which are not always popular but which I believe are right and which have proved to be right. I think back to my battles over the wheat quotas in the 1960s. Nobody wanted them, everybody was against me, but I was proved to be right and the quotas were accepted. I remember the battles on import parity pricing of oil . Everybody was against it. It certainly was not popular. The public, if a poll had been conducted, would have voted 100 per cent against it but it was in the national interest, it was right and it was accepted. Things are not always popular but sometimes they have to be done. If we are guided in our actions simply by what we think is popular we do not deserve the responsibility that the electorate has given to us.

The Liberal Party and the National Party have different views on this Bill. We in the National Party support it for reasons which I believe are sound while our colleagues in the Liberal Party oppose it for reasons which they believe are sound. I suppose that in a very mild way it is a bit like the kind of situation one gets in the Labor Caucus. The difference is, of course, that the Labor Caucus seems to split down the middle all the time with a vast gulf between the left wing and the right wing, the centre unity group and all the other odds and sods that turn up in the Labor Party. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is fond of describing this confused rabble as a magnificent example of the forces of democracy at work. The fact is that the differences between the various factions of the Labor Party are not minor. They are divided on great issues of principle and on issues of fundamental importance to the nation. The proposal to enlarge the Parliament is important, but I suggest it is hardly of earth shattering dimensions, and the difference approaches to it by the National Party and the Liberal Party will cause few people to sleep unsoundly in their beds tonight. Of course, the difference is to some extent one of degree in that the Liberal Party , while accepting that there may be a case for an increase in the future, feels that now is not the appropriate time. (Extension of time granted) I thank the House for its indulgence. I believe this is a tremendously important issue for this Parliament and for the nation. That is why I am trying to give it this considered approach.

It is almost 35 years since the size of the Parliament was last increased. I do not think anyone would suggest that the work of the Parliament and the work load of members and senators has not increased substantially over that period. Not only has there been almost a doubling of the numbers of voters; there has also been a doubling of the number of people in Australia. We represent not only voters; we represent everyone in the community. Not only are there many more people to be represented here; there are also many more issues to be dealt with because of the range of responsibilities of the Federal Parliament. The Federal Government has increased enormously in recent years. In some ways this concentration of responsibility is regrettable. It is certainly regrettable that , under the present Government with its strong bias towards centralism, the weakening of the Federal system and the breaking down of the responsibilities and powers of the States, this trend is likely to accelerate. The fact is that this Parliament must deal with a vastly greater range of matters than in earlier years. Also, each member and senator must deal not only with more people but also with a much greater range and diversity of matters that affect people. Those of us who represent growing electorates know this only too well. In my electorate of Richmond there were 41,516 voters in 1958. Today, mainly because of the rapid influx of people who want to live in the best part of Australia, there are more than 85,000 voters. My job and the job of every member is to represent not just voters but all the people. In my electorate there would be at least 140,000 people whom it is my duty to represent. A few years ago a member of parliament did not have even an electorate office. When I first became a member of this Parliament I had an office in the Commonwealth Bank building in Sydney-the Federal parliamentary rooms. I had a secretary who lived in Sydney. All other members had an office there. Things have changed vastly since then. Today I have an electorate office with two staff who are in heavy demand to meet the requirements of constituents and to try to give them service and advice. I doubt whether two people could be more intensely worked than those two people. I am sure other members' staff work equally hard. With 29 per cent or 30 per cent unemployment in the area, the job of my staff is absolutely enormous. Of course, in the big country electorates the problem seems to get even worse. The country electorates are getting bigger and bigger and I think it is quite unreasonable and almost humanly impossible to expect members in these large electorates to meet the demands of their constituents. Every member who represents these electorates would be badgered constantly by the complaint: 'We never see you. Why are you not here more often?' It is not possible to do that and that is all there is to it.

The range of legislation on the statute book has increased enormously. Of course, the size of the Executive has increased by 70 per cent since 1949. The pool of members in the legislature for government to draw from for Executive positions is declining. As the number of members in the Executive increases, the number of back benchers in the legislature declines. I do not believe it makes for the proper workings of government for the Executive to dominate so. Today the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) virtually has control of 34 people whom he has the influence to appoint to the positions they hold. One cannot get a proper expression or reflection of the feelings and views that members wish to express in the Caucus or the Party room if that group is under his influence. The situation can be improved only if the numbers are increased. Such a state of affairs is not good or healthy for proper Party room expression.

Of course, the number of committees of this Parliament has increased vastly. I notice that in the last 20 years the number of Senate committees-I am not talking about party committees-has increased from 13 to 33. Of course, there has also been a substantial increase in the number of committees of this House. Not that I believe in the committee system, but I think it is inevitable that we will need more and more committees if we are to carry out surveillance of departmental operations and the general workings of government and if we are to scrutinise legislation properly before it comes into this House for consideration. However, the fact is that we cannot properly service committees today. I have seen what happens. People going from one committee to another run into each other in the corridors. It is a crazy situation. Committees are not being attended in the way they should be. One finds only a token group of members when one goes to the dining room for a meal. When one asks where the other members are, one is told: 'Oh, they are having committee meetings during the meal recess'. One finds the chamber half vacant while debates are taking place. Where are the members? They are not necessarily working in their offices. In many cases they are attending committee meetings which are equally as important in their estimation as attending the workings of this Parliament. The argument for an increase in the number of members is very compelling indeed. I find it difficult to realise that people do not go along with it.

One also has to consider the physical size of electorates. Those of us who represent country electorates have found that as the population of Australia has grown our electorates too have become larger not only in terms of voters and people but also in terms of area. The number of country electorates has tended to fall. New South Wales has four fewer electorates now than there were in 1949. This means that members from New South Wales country areas must represent more people spread over much larger areas. For example, the number of voters in the electorate of the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt)-of course, he has represented it magnificently-has increased by 62 per cent and the area by over 300 per cent since the honourable member was elected. Yet many people in the community cannot see any need for some action to make more sensible and appropriate working arrangements for Parliament and for the people it represents .

Part of the folklore, as I have said, is that country electorates have far fewer voters than do city electorates. There should be fewer voters in country electorates than in city electorates in the interests of real fairness and quality of representation. However, the fact is that today city electorates in New South Wales on average have fewer voters than do country electorates. Small, compact city electorates which are far easier to service have fewer voters than vast country electorates with all the difficulties of servicing that they have. I believe that the modest increase in the size of Parliament that is now proposed is a sensible and appropriate response to this situation.

However, of course, there are other significant factors. I realise that I have been given the indulgence of the House to speak for longer than is allowed. I would like to say more. I have come into this debate believing in all sincerity that this is the right decision. I will be very disappointed if the people misconstrue the genuine contribution of my party, the National Party of Australia, and the genuine and sincere reasons why it wants to see an increase in the size of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I am bound to refer honourable members again to page 206 of Hansard of 4 May 1983. The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), the spokesperson for the Liberal Party and the Opposition in these matters, moved an amendment to the motion to appoint a Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform seeking to insert the following new sub- paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: (g) electoral distribution and numbers of Members of Parliament, procedures and systems.
In the course of supporting the amendment, the honourable member for Boothby said:
I have included this as an additional point of study and recommendation for the Minister's consideration because the number of members of parliament is a very important aspect.

Because of the obvious value it would be to the community I hope that he can see his way clear to express an opinion on this quite important matter of the number of representatives in this House and the other House.

His subsequent contribution to the House has been breathtaking in its philosophical flexibility. He has, with some confected outrage, come into this House and slammed these proposals quite simply because he is in the luxurious position of not having to treat them on their merits. As the proposals will go through, simply because of support from the National Party and broad bipartisan support from the Joint Select Committee, including qualified support from Senator Sir John Carrick, it is very easy for members of the Liberal Party to luxuriate in the position of being able to score a cheap political point or two. Let us get back to some of the figures we are looking at. In my own State of Victoria the average enrolment is 75,663 electors for each division. That is an 82.3 per cent increase since the last redistribution. Even taking into account these proposals, the actual increase in electors during that period will still be in the order of 54 per cent-a significant increase.

The increased workload of members of parliament has been adequately addressed by previous speakers. I shall not spend any time reiterating those arguments. There is one aspect, however, that has not been addressed, that is the implications for the democratic process of bringing the number of electors in each division thoughout Australia to a figure approaching equality. In Tasmania the five divisions currently have an enrolment of 56,493 electors on average. Of course, under these proposals that figure will not change but certainly the average number of electors in each division throughout Australia will. The average enrolment will drop from 74,989 to 63,335. It is a significant differential in those divisions but it is a move in the right direction towards the fundamental principle of one vote one value.

A moment ago, a member of the Liberal component of the Opposition, when he addressed this matter, expressed some outrage at what implicitly was a misinterpretation of Senator Sir John Carrick's position. Let me say at the outset that his qualification certainly was that because of the recession one ought not to go fully down this road at the moment and that it would seem to be an inopportune time to move. In addressing the principle we can all argue about whether it is the appropriate time or not, or indeed whether there ever will be an appropriate time with regard to these matters. They will inevitably be electorally unpopular and, as the Leader of the National Party (Mr Anthony) has indicated, one ought not to resile from making hard decisions simply because they will be electorally unpopular. I seem to recall a reasonably successful Prime Minister who, when leading the now Opposition, elevated the making of unpopular decisions to an art form and for some considerable time had a fairly successful electoral record. Let me quote from the dissenting report of Senator Sir John Carrick. On page 235 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform he said:

Many of the arguments adduced for an enlarged parliament are cogent. The Australian population has grown rapidly since 1948 (almost doubled) and the demands upon parliamentarians in a more complex social framework have greatly increased.
Certainly the extra burden cannot be fully met simply by increasing the size of the member's personal staff. The community will continue to demand the personal presence and attentions of the member.

Here we have the germ of another dispute in the Liberal Party. Of course, the honourable member for Boothby has made great play of the alternative of increasing the number of staff as one way in which we might resolve the problems of the significantly increased demands on parliamentarians. That is not a view embraced by his colleague on the Joint Select Committee, Senator Sir John Carrick, who further said:
In my view, while the logic of a larger parliament is strong, the overriding restraints of the current economic period must prevail.

I add that simply to be fair to the honourable senator and to put on record the points to which I adverted earlier. He did say that many of the arguments adduced for an enlarged Parliament are cogent, and he went on to agree with it in principle, while not supporting it for the moment on the grounds of economic needs.

A range of matters were adduced by the various honourable members who spoke prior to me. I simply want to say that, as a relatively new member of the Parliament and as one of the members of the Joint Select Committee, my views on this matter have not been based upon the premise of adopting the most cynical position. I personally do not believe that the Australian Labor Party will be advantaged by these proposals and I certainly do not embrace the view which some of the Liberal members seem to embrace that their Party will be necessarily disadvantaged. There are so many variables which might touch upon the results of any election that they are at the most only of marginal import.

The subject of the work load of honourable members was addressed by the Leader of the National Party and it was certainly addressed in some detail. I do not think that honourable members need reminding, but people listening might be interested to get some idea of the work load of an ordinary humble back bencher in this Parliament. I have had employment in the past when I have worked like the proverbial drover's dog, but I must say with all sincerity that I have never had employment which has demanded quite so much in terms of application or time as has this form of employment. I know that might be greeted with some cynicism in terms of the electorate, but that remains the case. The view that there ought to be an increased Parliament was not a submission of the Australian Labor Party , but that of itself is not a reason to reject it.

One proposal from the Australian Labor Party was that variations in electoral enrolments ought not to vary by anything greater than 5 per cent. On the basis of the submissions put before the Committee and against my original intuitive feeling on that matter the Joint Select Committee unanimously agreed that the variation ought to remain at 10 per cent. That was because the arguments put before the Committee were compelling in their logic. I simply wish to put on record that my views on this matter changed because of the logic of the case. It had nothing to do with any other factors that, implicitly, the honourable member for Boothby was imputing to those members of the Joint Select Committee who did not support his point of view.

My commitments in the Federal Parliament-I would assume it is a fairly average work load for a new back bencher-include my membership of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform which has been, quite clearly, a significant work load in the last few months. I am also a member of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege which involves a reasonably heavy work load, although not quite as heavy, of course, as the work load involved with the Electoral Reform Committee. I am a member of the House Committee on Privileges. I cannot claim that that has been a particularly heavy work load, although in certain circumstances--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not yet. Wait until after my motion.

—I shall be having something to say about the motion of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) in due course too. In any event I am also a member of the Caucus foreign affairs and defence committee, the Caucus economics committee and some three or four sub-committees of those committees. In terms of Party involvement, I am a member of the Victoria State Administrative Committee, the Victorian State Campaign Committee and the Civil Rights and Law Reform Committee. One could go on. Quite clearly, that is the sort of work load that many members need to fill. They are all important parts of the functioning of this Parliament.
—You will not be one of the 13 oncers.
—Order! The honourable member for Denison will cease interjecting.
—I am not too concerned about those types of interjections.
—Well, they are annoying me.
—I complimented you.

—It is not often that I am complimented by the honourable member for Denison. In any event, that is for public consumption. Certainly the honourable members in this place are quite well aware of the sorts of demands placed upon us. I simply say in concluding that the strength of the parliamentary system and of the Parliament, as opposed to the Executive, is predicated substantially upon the need for back benchers to have the time and resources to make a proper contribution to the governments of this country. That will not be the case when the work load is simply too big for even the most assidious and hard-working back benchers to handle properly. When the honourable member for Boothby was in this House with his confected outrage-I believe having forgotten that he moved the motions to which I adverted earlier-I suspect that that may have been a function of a significant work load. It is surprising in the extreme that someone could have come into this House, moved the motions, put the views he put and, some months later, come into the same chamber and attack the very proposals that he actually moved in the House. I shall not go on.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect of an increased Parliament, the fact that, for example, in the House of Commons the back bench involvement in parliamentary reform and the various Bills that come through the House is significantly greater than it is in this House-that was made clear by the submission of Professor Gordon Reid-the larger pool of talent from which the Executive might be chosen and so on, are all fundamental reasons why we must take this unpopular decision. I personally believe that this may damage the Government electorally but that, of itself, is no reason to resile from taking a decision that is in the best interests of this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the proposals we have before us to extend the size of this Federal Parliament and I do so for three fundamental reasons. Firstly, I believe that instead of focusing on increasing the size of the Parliament to cope with its existing work load, we should look primarily at reducing the size of government and the work of this Parliament. Secondly, I do not believe that we can support a reduction in the size of electorates, in effect voting ourselves an easier job, at a time when Australia is facing such difficult economic circumstances and when so many Australians are being asked to tighten their belts. Thirdly, I do not believe that we can support an increase in the number of parliamentarians when that proposition was never put to the electors and quite clearly flouts the wishes of the great majority of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go on to develop these points I want to put to rest the allegations that have been made by the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) and the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) concerning the amendment moved on 4 May by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). It is a subject of great concern to some people. If this is included in the terms agreed to by the Minister it would allow members of the public to give their views as to whether there should be more members of parliament, whether the status quo should be retained or whether there should be fewer members of parliament.
Honourable members opposite can criticise the honourable member for Boothby for the principle of his argument if they like but they cannot criticise him for putting it forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep reading.

—I will keep reading after the duplicitous remarks that the honourable member for Maribyrnong came out with tonight. Both he and the honourable member for Prospect were downright dishonest. The downright dishonesty of their remarks is exceeded only by their duplicity and they ought to be nailed for it. I will go on and they will see that the honourable member for Boothby was expanding on this point that it ought to be examined. Having said that we should look at whether there should be more members of parliament, whether the status quo should be retained or whether there should be fewer members of parliament he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Every member of this House in moving around his electorate would have heard views one way or the other on this issue. I recommend to the Minister for his consideration, and I hope acceptance, this addition to paragraph (1) (g). Because of the obvious value it would be to the community--
that is, to get that reference in (1) (g)-

He got that accepted and, when he had listened to argument, he put in a dissenting report. He had it examined and he put his opposition in a dissenting report. Then he came in, consistent to the end, arguing the case against additional members for the Parliament. The tortuous form of logic that the honourable member for Maribyrnong so dishonestly intrudes into this debate speaks for itself as to why he ought not even to be in this Parliament if he cannot tell the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —You won't be in the Parliament much longer.
—Selective misquotation is an attempt at selective morality and that is what--
— Order! The House will come to order.
—I will not have my members berated by his dishonest remarks.
